title: There are five measurements. 9.97,9.76,9.83,9.71 & 9.67. How do I find the percentage difference of these measurements? (accepted value = 9.81) - Quora

response.answer_text: Pay close attention to the words: the problem asks for the “percentage difference”. In order to get a difference you need to subtract two values: You always subtract the reference value (you call it “accepted value”) from your measurement. If your measurement is larger than your reference, you’ll get a positive result; if smaller, you’ll get a negative result. OK, we got the difference. How do we find “percentage difference”? Percentage is really the ratio of two values, multiplied by 100. Guess what two values we’ll use: One is the difference we just calculated. The other is the reference value, again. You divide the difference by your reference value, and you multiply by 100. What all this calculation does is tell you how much your measurement differs from the reference value, as a percentage of that reference value. And, if it’s a positive value, your measurement is larger than the reference; if it’s negative, your measurement is smaller than the reference by that percentage. OK, enough talk. Let’s do one example: Get the difference: 9.97–9.81=0.16 Find the ratio: 0.16/9.81=0.0163 Convert to percentage: 0.0163x100=1.63 So, for your first measurement, the percentage difference from the accepted value is 1.63%. It’s positive, so your measurement is larger than the accepted value, which you can also easily confirm by comparing the two. Now you can do the rest on your own.
